Newark archbishop says all citizens should ‚Äòengage in the political process‚ÄôNEW YORK ‚Äì At a time of inflamed political rhetoric, where neither major party candidate fully represents Church teaching on the issues, Cardinal Joseph Tobin is reminding Catholics of their duty to actively participate in the political process.‚ÄúIn this time of political uncertainty, it‚Äôs tempting to be cynical about the motivations and tactics of politicians and to want to disengage from politics, but in spite of what people often say, ‚Äòpolitics‚Äô is not a dirty word,‚Äù Tobin said. ‚ÄúIn fact, as Pope Francis forcefully reminds us, committed Christians and faithful... -
Joe Biden Implies He Would Attend Donald Trump‚Äôs Inauguration: ‚ÄòI Have Good Manners
President Joe Biden implied Tuesday that he will attend an inauguration for former President Donald Trump if he wins the election in November against Vice President Kamala Harris. When a reporter asked Biden if he would attend Trump‚Äôs inauguration, he implied that he would attend, adding that he has ‚Äúgood manners.‚Äù ‚ÄúMr. President, if Trump wins, will you attend his inauguration, sir?‚Äù the reporter asked. ‚ÄúFor the peaceful transfer of power?‚Äù -
Kenyan Farmer Wants Activists To Experience Agriculture Without Fossil Fuels
Jusper Machogu, a farmer in Kenya, Africa, wants people who think Africa shouldn‚Äôt develop with fossil fuels to see what a low-carbon lifestyle is really like. He and his family live it every day, and he told Cowboy State Daily that people, especially those of the West, don‚Äôt really grasp what it means not to have access to energy. In an effort to combat global emissions, wealthy nations are trying to discourage African countries from using fossil fuels, which Machogu said that will keep Africa in poverty. That‚Äôs why he‚Äôs offering an educational tour of his low-carbon lifestyle, which he... -
Initiative to enshrine abortion rights in Missouri constitution qualifies for November ballot
Missouri voters will decide in November whether to guarantee a right to abortion with a constitutional amendment that would reverse the state‚Äôs near-total ban. The secretary of state‚Äôs office certified Tuesday that an initiative petition received more than enough valid signatures from registered voters to qualify for the general election. It will need approval from a majority of voters to become enshrined in the state constitution. If passed, the Missouri initiative would ‚Äúdo something that no other state has done before ‚Äî end a total abortion ban at the ballot box,‚Äù said Rachel Sweet, campaign manager for Missourians for Constitutional... -
Harris-Walz Campaign Gets Busted Spoofing News Outlets in Headline-Altering Ad Scheme
Despite corporate media‚Äôs unabashed u-turn to support Kamala Harris, her campaign has been busted creating made-up headlines next to the names of real news outlets to trick people into thinking they‚Äôve stumbled upon the real thing, Axios reports. Upon hearing the news, The Guardian lost their sh*t, telling Axios: ‚ÄúWhile we understand why an organization might wish to align itself with the Guardian‚Äôs trusted brand, we need to ensure it is being used appropriately and with our permission. We‚Äôll be reaching out to Google for more information about this practice.‚Äù -

Tracking Kamala Harris‚Äô Biggest And Baddest Lies: 20 And Counting
Democrats traded one liar for another when they replaced their presumptive 2024 presidential nominee President Joe Biden with Vice President Kamala Harris. Harris may not quite live up to her counterpart‚Äôs long history of selling whoppers as truth, but there‚Äôs no doubt that she has fibbed far too often without consequence or accountability. Democrats‚Äô new darling likely wants voters to be ‚Äúunburdened by what has been.‚Äù But not even her jumbled babble or unintelligible chattering can keep Harris‚Äô radical track record and history of deception under wraps. The Economic Mind of Tim Walz
In recent weeks, Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz burst from relative obscurity to co-headlining the Democratic presidential ticket. Walz‚Äôs career rocket launch was fueled by his cutting political rhetoric, folksy midwestern charm, jovial dad vibes, and progressive principles and accomplishments. Before Walz was governor and a vice presidential candidate, he wore many hats. He was a congressman, a high school teacher, a union member, a command sergeant major in the Army National Guard, a state-championship-winning high school football coach. While not as dramatic as the political transformation of his electoral counterpart JD Vance, Walz too had a political transformation over the... -
Maricopa County agrees to test ballot tabulators used in elections, not just backup machines
The Republican Party of Arizona has secured an agreement with the Maricopa County Board of Supervisors to test ballot tabulators used in elections, rather than only testing backup equipment.The agreement states that the board "will inform the Secretary of State that it wants the test to be of at least six of the tabulators and twelve of the accessible voting devices scheduled to be deployed to early voting locations and vote centers."On Tuesday, the Arizona GOP announced the agreement, reached with Maricopa County on Monday, to perform logic and accuracy testing on accessible voting machines and ballot tabulators that are... -
$350 Could Cost You Thousands: Wall Street Banks Clamp Down On Harris-Walz Donations
Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äôs selection of Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as her running mate has created an unexpected challenge for Wall Street‚Äôs political donors. Major financial institutions are now grappling with stringent regulations that could limit their employees‚Äô ability to contribute to the Harris-Walz campaign. At the heart of the issue, reported initially by Business Insider, is the Securities and Exchange Commission‚Äôs ‚Äúpay-to-play‚Äù rule, adopted in 2010. The regulation aims to prevent financial firms from influencing politicians through campaign contributions in hopes of securing lucrative government contracts, like managing state pension funds. -
Musk boasts of 1B views for 'no limits' X interview with Trump
Elon Musk‚Äôs conversational interview with former President Trump on Monday evening pulled in a combined 1 billion views, according to the tech billionaire. "Combined views of the conversation with @realDonaldTrump and subsequent discussion by other accounts now ~1 billion," Musk posted on his social media platform X early Tuesday morning following the interview. The message followed a previous post outlining that, "Between 7:47 PM and 10:47 PM ET, President Donald Trump's Space post received 73 million views. During the same period, there were 4 million posts about Elon Musk and President Trump's conversation on ùïè, generating a total of 998... -
Top Democrat Steny Hoyer, 85, suffers a stroke
A longtime Maryland Democrat and one of the longest-serving members in Congress survived a stroke over the weekend his team announced Tuesday. Rep. Steny Hoyer, 85, has represented Maryland in Congress since first being elected in 1981. 'On Sunday night, August 11, Rep. Steny Hoyer experienced a mild ischemic stroke and sought medical treatment,' Hoyer spokesperson Margaret Mulkerrin wrote in a statement. 'Mr. Hoyer has responded well to treatment and has no lingering symptoms. He expects to resume his normal schedule next week.' 'Mr. Hoyer‚Äôs wife and family extend their deepest thanks to his medical team,' the statement concluded. -

There was a particularly revealing set of quotes from unnamed Democrat ‚Äúinsiders‚Äù in Monday‚Äôs edition of Politico ‚ÄúPlaybook‚Äù that went like this: ‚ÄúValues unite and specific policies divide, so I don‚Äôt think there is a desire to spend the next 80 days litigating Medicare for All, for example,‚Äù and, ‚ÄúWhy would we start talking about policy?‚Äù In other words, Democrats feel no need whatsoever to run a campaign for president. Another New Study Finds Rising CO2 Enhances Planetary Greening and Reduces Drought Risk
‚Äú‚Ä¶elevated CO2 concentrations not only boosted vegetation growth through the fertilizer effect but also indirectly enhanced water availability [reducing drought risk] by improving water use efficiency.‚Äù ‚Äì Song et al., 2024 One of the more commonly-stated concerns linked to ‚Äúglobal warming‚Äù is that sweltering heat will parch the terrestrial landscape (browning), limit vegetation growth, and foment water shortages ‚Äì even widespread drought. However, a new study suggests the Earth‚Äôs rising CO2 concentration has the exact opposite effect in the real world. In their extensive trend analysis spanning the last few decades, the scientists determined elevated CO2 was the single most... -
The Failure of Interreligious Dialogue with Islam
The Failure of Interreligious Dialogue with IslamLast week, on the morning of August 7th, Pope Francis, just before his regular Wednesday general audience, received a group of representatives from the Afghan Muslim community in Italy. He touched upon the ‚Äúcomplicated and dramatic history [in Afghanistan], marked by a succession of wars and blood-stained conflicts, which have made it very difficult for people to lead peaceful, free and secure lives.‚Äù The pontiff went on to tell the Afghan males‚Äîthere were, surprisingly, no women at the encounter‚Äî‚Äúto continue in [their] noble endeavour to promote religious harmony and to strive to overcome misunderstandings... -
Biden: Iran could hold back on attack if Gaza deal reached
Iran is expected to skip a retaliatory strike on Israel if a Gaza ceasefire deal is reached, US President Joe Biden told reporters in New Orleans on Tuesday, stressing ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs my expectation.‚Äù Defense Minister Yoav Gallant left nothing to chance, stating in northern Israel that the IDF is prepared for defensive and offensive actions against Hezbollah and Iran, even as the United States pinned its hope for averting a regional war on Thursday‚Äôs hostage talks in Doha. The Press Won‚Äôt Discuss Real Campaign Issues, Because They Don‚Äôt Want Trump To Win
